clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Testing a Mobile App to Designed to Increase Physical Activity Among Pregnant and Postpartum Women
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Testing of a Mobile Health Intervention Designed to Increase Physical Activity and Improve Morbidity and Mortality-related Outcomes Among Pregnant and Postpartum Women in a Rural Setting

brief_summary.textblock:
The goal of this pilot project is to test the feasibility and potential efficacy of the evidence-based mHealth app (BumptUp) for improving physical activity and subsequent health outcomes (i.e. obesity, hypertension, insulin resistance) among pregnant and postpartum women in a rural community.
In order to accomplish this goal, feasibility of the intervention protocol will be tested by the assessment of recruitment (how many participants eligible per month), retention (% of women who complete the study protocol), adherence to intervention (% of women who utilize the app), and acceptability (survey and one-on-one exit interviews) during pregnancy and postpartum.
Potential efficacy will be determined by examining trends in data on physical activity levels (achieving the goal of 150 minutes per week of physical activity (surveys and accelerometry)) between groups. Other secondary outcomes will also be assessed: weight status, body composition, blood pressure, insulin resistance, endothelial function, fitness levels, mental health, and infant anthropometrics.
Clinical hypotheses:
1. The mHealth program will be feasible as evidenced by high rates of enrollment, retention, and adherence, moderate-to-high levels of satisfaction, and low participant burden.
2. The mHealth intervention will show promise towards improving physical activity levels and other secondary outcomes in pregnant and postpartum women in a rural community.

detailed_description.textblock:
After contact is established and eligibility confirmed, Participants (N=30) will come to the Body Composition Laboratory on three separate occasions. The first will be baseline (~23-25 weeks pregnant), late pregnancy (35-37 weeks pregnant), and ~12 weeks postpartum. There will also be two check-ins via telephone (one during pregnancy and one during postpartum upon medical clearance at ~6 weeks) to aid with retention, as well as allow participants to ask any questions about the app or the educational brochure. At each visit, the study procedures will be identical and follow the assessment procedures outlined below. Time points were chosen as women tend to become the least active during late pregnancy; and transitioning back into activity during the early postpartum days is important for long-term sustained activity. After the baseline assessment (~23-25 weeks gestation), the women will be randomized to the intervention or control group. The control group will receive an evidence-based educational brochure about physical activity during pregnancy. The intervention group will receive free access to the mobile app developed by our team (BumptUp). BumptUp users will watch an introductory video on the app's features and the goal of the app (i.e. to reach the recommended 150 minutes per week of physical activity). The app contains evidence-based workout information and education as well as a number of resources aimed at increasing physical activity for women during and after pregnancy (key features of the app are located in Table 1). Adherence will be assessed via how many weeks they used the app (PI will have access these data).
When a participant completes all study procedures, a final satisfaction survey and exit interview will take place to determine acceptability of the protocol and participant burden. For this reason, a number of secondary outcomes are being included in this pilot in order to finalize the study protocol (and not necessarily to determine the result of the intervention on outcomes). App satisfaction will be assessed in the intervention group only via a survey adapted by our team. If a participant drops out before completing the study, all attempts will be made to conduct the exit interview and to determine the reason for drop out. Exit interviews will be recorded, transcribed, and coded for themes via standard qualitative analyses64.
Assessment Procedures: Participants will report to the laboratory at approximately 8:00am after a 10-hour fast. The participant's weight, height, and vitals (heart rate and blood pressure) will be taken upon arrival after resting for ~10minutes. Body composition will be measured using skinfold anthropometry in order to determine maternal percent body fat. Body fat percentage will be determined by pressing folds of the skin at seven sites with a caliper (Harpenden Skinfolds Caliper, Baty International) and entering the data into a standardized equation65, a technique that has been used during pregnancy in prior studies66,67. In addition, the participant will complete an Air Displacement Plethysmography assessment with a certified technician (BodPod) (COSMED), which has been shown to be valid among pregnant women, as well as non-gravid (postpartum) women, if thoracic gas volume is measured directly. After the baseline vitals and body composition assessments, a blood draw will be obtained via standardized procedures successfully used in the Tinius Lab70. Blood draws will be used to analyze insulin using standardized protocols in the Exercise Biochemistry Lab at WKU (Biosafety Level 2 Certified). A lipid panel (total cholesterol, HDL, LDL, triglycerides, and glucose) will be obtained via Cholestech LDX analyzer (Alere). Baseline insulin and glucose levels will be used to calculate the homeostatic model assessment-insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), an index of insulin resistance. Because endothelial dysfunction is the earliest detectable sign of cardiovascular and metabolic disease, and because exercise in non-pregnant adults can improve it; endothelial dysfunction will be assessed with a rapid, non-invasive technique that records endothelium-mediated changes in the peripheral arterial tone signal via a pair of finger probes.73 (Endopat, Itamar Medical). This will provide additional information on the potential for development of insulin resistance, hypertension, and obesity75 -all of which are linked to maternal morbidity and mortality. To elaborate, the intervention may not necessarily change blood pressure or insulin resistance to a clinically significant degree (i.e. may not take a patient from hypertensive to normotensive), but it may favorably impact endothelial health, which suggests factors underlying the hypertension are improving. In addition, the impact of physical activity during pregnancy on endothelial function is lacking. Taken together, this additional assessment via the EndoPat adds to the novelty of the proposed project, provides another clinically relevant layer of information regarding health status during pregnancy, and increases the overall research capacity at WKU for this study and future pregnancy and postpartum research.
Following the blood draw, the participant will complete the 6-minute walk test utilizing standardized procedures to estimate their physical fitness76. Dr. Tinius and her team have extensive experience conducting this test among pregnant women, and the test has been shown to provide a valid estimate of fitness during pregnancy and in non-gravid adults (i.e. postpartum)76. In order to assess the primary outcome (Aim 2), participants will be asked to wear a Link Accelerometer (ActiGraph LLC,) for seven consecutive days. Wrist-worn tri-axel accelerometers are a valid measure of physical activity in pregnant women78. The accelerometer will be placed on their non-dominant wrist at the end of their study visit to the Exercise Laboratory and will be picked up by a member of the study team one week later. The participant will verbally complete the Exercise Vital Sign survey; a survey specifically designed to determine whether someone meets 150min of physical activity per week. The participant will also be provided with a number of written surveys (See Appendix A). These surveys will assess a number of additional outcomes for inclusion in the larger future clinical trial the current pilot study will help the study team determine the participant burden and whether or not this number of surveys is feasible for the larger trial. Each survey has been selected to determine the potential impact of the mHealth program on a particular outcome related to morbidity and mortality. As an example, mental health surveys are included as postpartum depression plays a significant role in maternal morbidity and mortality, and physical activity improves depressive symptoms during and after pregnancy.
Infant and Delivery Outcome Assessment: Before being discharged from the hospital after parturition, the study team will coordinate with the mothers and their nursing team a time to assess the infant as well as collect delivery outcome data from the mother (mode of delivery, length of labor, complications, mother's end pregnancy weight). Infant measurements will include skinfolds at four sites (hip, thigh, arm, and back), length, head circumference, and abdominal circumference. In addition, infant body composition will be via measured air displacement plethysmography system (PeaPod, COSMED).
Statistical Analyses:
Sample Size Determination: Sample size for this pilot study was determined based on previously performed physical activity interventions among pregnant women. The effect size (0.91) for the main outcome of physical activity was determined from looking at post-intervention physical activity data from Asci et al.83. With this effect size, it was determined using SAS software with a type I error rate of 0.05 that a sample size of 20 per group could detect this difference with 80% power, thus our sample size of 15 per group is justified for a pilot project.
Data Analyses:
Aim 1: To estimate the success and feasibility of recruitment methods, the number of people who will hear about the study via various methods (e.g. health care providers, health fairs, word-of-mouth) will be estimated. Then, the number of women who completed initial screening, the number of women who meet the eligibility criteria, the number of women who complete each of the assessments, the number of women randomized, and the number of women who adhere to the intervention will be determined. The exit interview data will be analyzed via standard content analyses for qualitative studies as previously described84 (and recently performed by our group). Aim 2: Although we may not detect all between group differences because we are proposing a pilot project, appropriate statistical tests will be performed in order to examine trends, and thus, promise for effect in the larger future trial. Normality of the distribution for each variable will be tested using Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests, and non-normally distributed data will be transformed as needed. The baseline characteristics of the two groups will be compared using t-tests or Chi square tests. The potential effect of the intervention on study outcomes will be explored using repeated measures ANOVAs (group x time). Specifically, physical activity data between groups will be compared from pre-post intervention. All data will be entered in Redcap data management system. Analyses will be conducted using SAS or other statistical software.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Pregnant women will be recruited ~20 weeks pregnant and after baseline assessments, randomized into the control or intervention group. The intervention group will utilize the mhealth intervention, while the control group will receive basic educational materials only.
study_design_info.masking_description: The participant (as well as the study team and the health care provider) will know after randomization whether or not they are being provided access to the mobile app.

arm_group.description: This group will be provided with the mobile health app (including introductory videos on how to use its features).
This group will receive an educational brochure about physical activity during pregnancy.

intervention.description: Access to the mobile health application with exercise plans and education
An evidence-based educational brochure with general information about the benefits of physical activity during pregnancy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 1) Age 18-44
- 2) Confirmed singleton viable pregnancy
- 3) English-Speaking (the app is currently only available in English)
- 4) Physician release to participate in exercise
- 5) Ownership of a smart phone
- 6) Plans to deliver at The Medical Center in Bowling Green, KY.
Exclusion Criteria:
- 1) Multiple gestation pregnancy
- 2) Inability to provide voluntary informed consent
- 3) Any medical condition (pregnancy-related or not) that would preclude exercise.
